config.question: Why did the New Netherland colonists offer no opposition to the British order to surrender?

choices.content: The British allowed Dutch nationals to retain their property if they surrendered.
The colonists were told to surrender by the director-general of New Netherland.
The majority of the residents in the colony were originally from England.
The surrender agreement had provisions for an elected assembly and democracy.

answer_3.response: The New Netherland colonists accepted the order to surrender without any opposition. This was due to a generous agreement that allowed Dutch nationals to remain in the province and retain their property under English rule.
